title: Antony Hignell
text:
Antony Francis Hignell (6 July 1928 – 23 October 2015) was an English <a href="cricket">cricket</a>er and <a href="javelin%20throw">javelin throw</a>er. 
Cricket career.
He was a right-handed batsman and right-arm medium-pace bowler who played for <a href="Gloucestershire%20County%20Cricket%20Club">Gloucestershire</a>. He was born in <a href="Kroonstad">Kroonstad</a>.
Hignell made a single first-class appearance for the team, during the 1947 season, against <a href="Cambridge%20University%20Cricket%20Club">Cambridge University</a>. He scored 7 runs in the only innings in which he batted, and conceded 48 runs with the ball in 18 overs.
Hignell played for Gloucestershire Second XI in the Minor Counties Championship during the 1948 season.
Athletics career.
In 1949 he was <a href="Amateur%20Athletic%20Association%20of%20England">AAA</a> champion in the javelin event, and represented <a href="England%20at%20the%201950%20British%20Empire%20Games">England</a> in 1950 where he placed fourth at the <a href="Athletics%20at%20the%201950%20British%20Empire%20Games">British Empire Games in Auckland</a>.
Personal life.
He was the father of <a href="Alastair%20Hignell">Alastair Hignell</a>, who played cricket for <a href="Cambridge%20University%20Cricket%20Club">Cambridge University</a> and Gloucestershire and <a href="rugby%20union">rugby union</a> for <a href="England%20rugby%20union%20team">England</a>, <a href="Cambridge%20University%20Rugby%20Football%20Club">Cambridge University</a> and <a href="Bristol%20Rugby%20Football%20Club">Bristol</a>.
Hignell died on 23 October 2015 at the age of 87.
